explanation:
Why each symbol is required:

- MHD_BASE64_FUNC_VERSION
  - Controls conditional compilation inside the function: (a) whether the map[] is extended to cover 0x80..0xFF, and (b) whether the extra 0x80 input-bit checks (for version 2) are present. The map size and these checks directly affect whether map[(c)] indexing and in[i] checks can access out of bounds or prevent illegal input values.

- MHD_base64_map_type_
  - The element type of map[]. The code relies on negative sentinel values (-1, -2) and on comparisons like (0 > v1). Knowing this typedef (signedness and width) is necessary to reason about the comparisons, conversions to uint8_t when assembling output bytes, and whether the stored sentinel values are representable without undefined behavior.

- static const MHD_base64_map_type_ map[]
  - Although shown in the function, the effective length/content depends on MHD_BASE64_FUNC_VERSION. The exact number of elements determines whether indexing map[(c)] with (uint8_t) values (0..255) can go out of bounds. Analysis must use the actual compiled map contents.

- base64_char_to_value_ (macro)
  - Expands to map[(c)] (when MHD_BASE64_FUNC_VERSION >= 2). The macro is the direct site of the map indexing; to verify no out-of-bounds access we must consider its expansion and any potential side-effects/assumptions.

- mhd_assert
  - Used once before writing the first byte of the last block. The semantics (no-op in production vs. aborting/checking) affect whether a failing assertion could mask or allow a subsequent out-of-bounds write during analysis. Knowing whether it can be relied on to prevent further execution is necessary for safety reasoning.

- MHD_basic_auth_get_username_password3
  - The static call graph shows this function calls MHD_base64_to_bin_n. To determine whether the target can cause out-of-bounds writes/reads at call sites you must inspect the caller(s) to see how base64, base64_len, bin and bin_size are computed/passed (allocated sizes, checked invariants). The correctness of the size checks inside MHD_base64_to_bin_n in context depends on how callers provide bin_size and base64_len.

- uint8_t typedef (stdint.h)
  - The function casts incoming base64 bytes to uint8_t and uses those values as indices into map[]. Confirming that uint8_t is an 8-bit unsigned type and that the cast yields values in the 0..255 range is necessary to reason about possible map index values.

These symbols together let an analyzer determine (1) whether map[(c)] indexing can go out of bounds for any input byte value, (2) whether the checks on base64_len and bin_size are sufficient for all code paths that write to out[], and (3) whether any assertions or caller behavior affect the possibility of accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by pointer parameters.
